info.title: Handling Asynchronous Requests in Designetz
info.description:
This document describes a possible solution for dealing with asynchronous requests. It is suggested to use this method in _all_ services that are developed and used within the Designetz-project.

As an example, consider the following scenario: the creation of a new forecast for a solar power plant is known to take some time (minutes, possibly hours). Thus, just waiting for the response to a `POST`-request to the endpoint `/forecasts/solar-power` would most likely result in a timeout for the service consumer.

In order to avoid this, the server immediately responds to the request by sending a `202 Accepted` with a link to a resource exposing the current status (of the creation of the forecast). The client then polls this resource until it receives a `303 See Other` with the link to the resource that exposes the initially requested forecast.

![Sequence diagram](https://github.com/UdSAES/designetz_schemata/raw/master/resources/asynchronous_requests_uml_sequence.png)

Consequently, service developers have to take care of two scenarios:

1. __Processing a request received on a certain endpoint could take a long time due to some long-running background job.__ In this case, the server must _always_ process the request using the mechanism described above, even if it could be possible to respond immediately from time to time.

2. __When processing a request, another endpoint, which requires polling, is called.__ Again, the server must _always_ process the request using the mechanism described above.

References:
* [Farazgadi, Victor (2014): REST and long-running jobs. Personal blog.](https://farazdagi.com/2014/rest-and-long-running-jobs/)
* [Schreier, Silvia (no date): Long Running Operation with Polling. RESTalk-patterns.org](http://restalk-patterns.org/long-running-operation-polling.html)

post.summary: Creates a resource (requires the execution a long-running background job)

parameters.name: parameters_resource
parameters.description: The information necessary to create the desired resource

202.description: Indication that the request has been accepted for processing, but the processing has not been completed ([RFC7231, section 6.3.3](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-6.3.3))

Location.description: Referral to a specific resource in relation to the response ([RFC7231, section 7.1.2](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-7.1.2)), namely the resource to be polled until the long-running background job has finished

get.summary: The resource that provides the results of a long-running background job

parameters.name: uuid
parameters.description: The ID identifying the initially requested resource

200.description: A representation of the resource providing the results of a long-running background job

get.summary: A resource indicating the status of the long-running background job

parameters.name: uuid
parameters.description: An ID identifying an item in the processing queue

200.description: An acknowledgement that the poll has been processed successfully, but the background job is still running

status.description: The status of the background job, for example 'RUNNING'

303.description: referral to the initially requested resource that is now available ([RFC7231, section 6.4.4](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-6.4.4))

Location.description: Referral to a specific resource in relation to the response ([RFC7231, section 7.1.2](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-7.1.2)), namely the resource initially requested

tags.name: synchronous
tags.description: Requests that can be processed immediately, __not__ resulting in timeouts

tags.name: asynchronous
tags.description: Requests that can __not__ be processed immediately, likely resulting in timeouts
